area_name: Big Bald Brook to Carey Brook

climbs.name: Kluskap
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Luc Gallant, March 2019

content.description:
One of the best climbs in the park. Wild features, sustained and technical climbing, stunning position. A classic in every sense.
Pitch 1 - Climb the steep curtain off the beach. Undercut on the left but there should always be something touching down on the right. Move up and left, top out on a massive sloping ledge. Build a screw anchor somewhere up and right out of ice fall range.
Pitch 2 - Begin up the steep column underneath the umbrella roofs above. The line continues up then slightly left to find the most reasonable path out of the umbrellas and to the top. Be very careful where you place screws. Most of the protectable ice is not more than a few centimeters thick. You could also sling some columns for pro.

2.5 k north of Big Bald Brook. Find the amphitheater and drop in from either side. You could also rap to the beach at low tide on one of the nearby routes and walk to the base. 
A rack of screws. Tree anchor.

climbs.name: Kwimu
climbs.fa: Michel Martin and Greg Hughes, February 2020

content.description:
This is the line to the left of Kluskap. In the Mi'kmaq legend Kwimu was the faithful companion and messenger of Kluskap. Climb the first pitch off the beach or rap in to access the bowl. Take the line furthest left. On the fa it was a narrow line of ice that with a tricky section near the top.


The best way to get to this route is to rappel in to the Kluskap amphitheater/bowl. You can get to the bowl with one double rope rappel. From there either rap off v threads or build an anchor to rap down to the beach. The first pitch is worth doing if the tide permits. 
A rack of screws. Screw anchor for pitch 1 in the bowl and tree anchor at the top.

climbs.name: Lentuk
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Luc Gallant, March 2019

content.description:
Lentuk is the Mi'Kmaq word for deer. This is a really fun line and very aesthetic. 

Found 300 meters north of Kluskap.
A rack of screws.

Mui'n is the Bear, one of the most prominent animal spirits of Mi'kmaq mythology. As the name suggests this is a burly line. Sustained steep for two pitches.

About 100 meters south of the Keyhole Brook sign. This route faces north so it will come in early and stay late into the season. 
A rack of screws.Rap to the beach just north of the route after downclimbing  some third class to a good tree.

Climb the lower curtain, finish on the right hand pillar.



Past Keyhole brook about 1 km north you will find Carey brook. Use this as access to gain the beach. Puowini’skw is just north up the beach.

Ice screws

climbs.name: Put'p
climbs.fa: Luc Gallant, Craig Norris and Greg Hughes, March 2019

content.description:
Put'p is Kluskap’s companion, the whale, who carried him across the ocean.This route is the line to the right of Kluskap in the same amphitheater. Climb the first pitch of Kluskap and build a screw anchor belay. Step right and climb the nicely featured right hand wall.

Kluskap Amphitheatre 
A rack of screws. Tree anchor at top.

Tqoqwej is the Wildcat in the Mi'kmaw language. 
Pitch 1 - Climb a steep pitch off the beach to a left trending ramp. Follow the ramp up to another short slab of ice up to a belay. 40 meters
Pitch 2 - Choose a line up toward the umbrellas that you will be able to navigate around and find the top. There are two distinct lines to the top. We chose the line on the right. 35 meters

400 meters south of the Kluskap amphitheater. 
A rack of screws.

pathTokens: Big Bald Brook to Carey Brook

content.description:
The northwest coastline of the park contains a multitude of ice routes. This section of the coast is not as tall but there are some fantastic routes and more new routes await fa's.

*The names of the routes along this section of coast are all in the Mi'kmaq language. This area has a strong cultural significance to the first nations people who have lived here for thousands of years and the names reflect the legends, stories and names associated with this culture.
